body: Candidate for backporting to the 0.9.0 branch.

Thanks

LGTM. Merged to trunk.
Cherry-picked to 0.9.0 as well.

@apovzner @guozhangwang I updated the patch with Guozhang's proposal. I will add integration test in a separate PR. 
The intended tests are:
1. Change timestamp type on the fly.
2. Test message format version upgrade
I actually want to do end to end test using different version of producers and consumers. But not sure if it is possible the current integration test because that requires different clients jars.
Thanks @junrao, backport in https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/820
Tests passed locally.

Failure is not related to patch as it has only doc changes. Test was failed with topics was already exists. Failures might be because of running two builds simultaneously as two commits were pushed almost same time.
I just change parameter name, should pass jenkins... what's wrong?

@becketqin You can do end-to-end compatibility testing with system tests. Take a look at compatibility_test.py. It currently tests 0.9.X java producer against 0.8.X brokers and 0.8.X consumer against an 0.9.X brokers. They both succeed on expected failure. You can add couple of more system tests to that to test newer brokers with older producers and/or consumers. Note that you would need to update vagrant/base.sh to get Kafka release 0.9.0.0.

@becketqin Maybe I missed it, but I don't see where producer assigns timestamps if the user does not specify the timestamp in ProducerRecord. The code was there before, but maybe it got accidentally removed with recent changes?
@apovzner Thanks for the direction on compatibility test. Extracting timestamp type out makes sense, given we already did that for CompressionType. I will change server side as well.
Thanks @ijuma . Code is now ready for next round of review after accommodating the changes for above comments.

Nice catch, thanks for fixing this! I left a minor comment in the PR. Also, can you please edit the PR title to be something like:

`KAFKA-3103; Transient Failure in testIsrAfterBrokerShutDownAndJoinsBack` ?

I marked the other tickets as duplicates, so we just need to refer to the one actually.
cc @hachikuji
LGTM
LGTM
I've reopened KAFKA-3155 as @guozhangwang pointed out that the stacktrace looks different. @rowdyrabbit, can you explain how it's the same issue?

Seems fine to me. As Ewen said in the other PR, it's not great that we have no tests for these changes in behaviour. However, that was already the case and I don't think it should block the PR. Let's see what Ewen says.

Actually, it looks like KAFKA-3155 **is** a separate issue, I think it's just named poorly - it should be called:

Transient Failure in kafka.api.BaseProducerSendTest.testFlush 

and one occurrence is in kafka.api.PlaintextProducerSendTest.testFlush
Thanks @rowdyrabbit
Thanks @ZoneMayor, did you see this comment https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/693/files#r51100904 ?
Do we also need to update the windows (.bat) scripts?

Thinking out loud a bit here. Hopefully this doesn't derail too much:

Recent changes in the build have ensured we have consistent artifact versions across the modules. Because our build has a lot of inter-project dependencies we duplicate a lot of jars pulled from the dependent-libs directories onto the classpath, not just the slf4j ones. 

Would it make sense to change the build to generate a central dependent-libs directory with all of the de-duplicated jars? That can be done in this patch, or I am happy to do it with a new subtask under KAFKA-2787.

@granthenke It is a good question. Personally, I'd prefer if each command would only get the relevant jars in the classpath. A central dependent-libs directory makes that a bit harder, especially with wildcard classpath entries. Having said that, whatever solution we come up with has some drawbacks so I'm not actually sure what's the right thing to do here.

@ewencp What are your thoughts on the solution proposed here versus a central dependent-libs directory?

@ijuma I agree it would be optimal to have the correct classpath without extra jars. 

I like the approach used in this patch to only use the classpath of the need projects/modules. However, I think we could do it at build time instead of runtime. That way the scripts wouldn't need to "hardcode" their project dependencies and we could leave that logic in the gradle build. The gradle build is where we define what dependencies are required. We could still deduplicate jars too.

It makes the build a little more complicated, but one way to do this while building would be:
- place artifacts in a central lib dir
- place dependencies in a central deps dir
- symlink all deps from the central dirs in the modules dependency dir
  - Not sure about windows here as I am less familiar with linking
- use the changes in this patch that define the project and load that projects classpath only
  - Only difference is you only define 1 project, not multiple.
@ZoneMayor I apologize for not bringing this up earlier. Thank you for your persistence on this patch.

@becketqin  I reviewed the KIP-32 part of the patch (did not go in detail about KIP-31 related changes). Using timestamp type in attributes made producer/consumer code much cleaner! I made minor comments. Otherwise looks good to me.
LGTM. Merged to trunk and 0.9.0.

@granthenke Yes, using the gradle build to extract project dependencies is definitely better. Not sure about symlinking though, is the optimisation worth dealing with the potential compatibility issues?
Thanks for the PR. Can you please also fix AdminClientTest?
Unit test passed locally.
